user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_open_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_open_generic(const char *name, size_t size,
			     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem;
	struct metal_list *node;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list, node) {
		shmem = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_generic_shmem, node);
		if (strcmp(shmem->name, name) != 0)
			continue;
		if (size <= metal_io_region_size(&shmem->io)) {
			*result = &shmem->io;
			return 0;
		}
	}

	return -ENOENT;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function metal_shmem_open_generic:
#define metal_list_for_each(list, node) for((node)=(list)->next;(node)!=(list);(node)=(node)->next)
...
struct metal_list {
	struct metal_list *next, *prev;
}
...
extern struct metal_state _metal
...
#define metal_container_of(ptr, structure, member) (void*)((uintptr_t)(ptr)-metal_offset_of(structure,member))
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
...
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list, node) {
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 14.3 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The macro expands to: for ((node) = (list)->next; (node) != (list); (node) = (node)->next). The controlling expression is (node) != (list), and node is updated each iteration via (node) = (node)->next, so the expression is not invariant. Therefore Rule 14.3 is not violated.
